awd_titl_txt: Halogen Budget of Subducted Eclogites: The In-situ Perspective
awd_abstract_narration:
Halogen elements, such as fluorine and chlorine, play a fundamental role in a variety of Earth systems. They influence global climate, volcanic eruptions, biosphere properties, and the mechanical behavior of deep Earth materials. Although earthquake and volcanic hazards are linked to the abundance and distribution of these elements in fluid and mineral phases, critical gaps exist regarding the budgets and fluxes of halogens in the Earth's interior. In particular, large uncertainties remain on the quantities of halogens that are recycled at depth during subduction of seawater-rich tectonic plates, a process that currently occurs along 55,000 km of oceanic trenches worldwide. The best rock samples to study the budget of subducted tectonic plates, and their consequences on earthquake and volcanic hazards, are analogs of subducted oceanic plates called eclogites. However, halogen analyses of subduction-derived eclogites have been historically hampered by technical challenges, limiting our ability to correctly define halogen fluxes on Earth. Here we propose a novel combination of advanced analytical and imaging techniques to provide unique constraints on the halogen budget of subducting plates. The goal is to answer the following questions: how are halogens distributed in subducted plates, and how does their distribution influence societal hazards linked to subduction zones worldwide? The project will provide an opportunity for an internship for a student from a STEM-underrepresented group to work at Woods Hole and outreach efforts by the principal investigator.

Oceanic plates are created at mid-ocean ridges and recycled at depth in subduction zones, carrying back large amounts of halogens into the Earth?s mantle. Previous studies have made significant advances in understanding the dehydration and melting reactions that take place in subducting plates, but estimates of elemental fluxes remain largely debated. In particular, although bulk measurements of halogens provide valuable information into elemental cycling, the contributions from crystal grains, grain boundaries, fluid inclusions and incipient alteration cannot be distinguished through that technique and can lead to severely skewed estimates of halogen fluxes on Earth. Here we propose to take advantage of recent technical developments led by the PI at the Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution ion microprobe facility to provide, for the first time, an in-situ distribution map of halogens in subducted eclogites. We will use a novel combination of techniques - in-situ SIMS; micro-CT scanning; ion chromatography; pyrohydrolysis - to quantify the contribution from crystal grains, grain boundaries, fluid inclusions and incipient alteration in eclogite samples representative of various subduction conditions worldwide. Using fresh and well-characterized samples from these localities, we will determine how halogen distribution may vary in subduction zones and calculate new halogen fluxes. This combination of techniques has never been proposed before, is highly complementary to bulk approaches that have been historically used, and will provide critical insight into halogen fluxes in subduction zones. The PI will participate in a WHOI program that provides internships for students who are from underrepresented groups.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project aimed at studying the chemical composition of oceanic rocks that form on the seafloor during volcanic events and are recycled back into the deep Earth tens to hundreds of million years later due to tectonic forces. As they dive back to depths of hundreds of kilometers beneath the surface (process of ‘subduction’), they carry large amounts of seawater-derived elements such as hydrogen, which is a constituent of water, and chlorine, the halogen element of table salt. These elements play a significant role in modifying the nature of lavas that are produced in arc volcanos such as, for example, in the Cascades. Hydrogen and chlorine may make lavas more explosive and trigger the formation of hazardous volcanic gases. Our study aimed to better understand the recycling process of these elements in the deep Earth and advance the understanding of hazardous volcanic regions.

The project provided the opportunity to train one summer undergraduate student and three PhD students, including two from the MIT-WHOI Joint Program. The main technique used in this project (called ‘SIMS’) is an advanced analytical technique to measure hydrogen and chlorine in minerals (among other elements) and has been developed in selected laboratories worldwide, typically those specialized in Earth sciences or Material sciences. The project involved collaborations between scientists based in the US, Germany, and France. The results have been presented orally by the PI and her advisees to the general public, to academic audiences at scientific seminars and to experts at international conferences. The project produced three papers in international journals, including an invited contribution with a student as a lead author, and will lead to the publication of at least three more manuscripts beyond its final date. In the papers we published, we determined for example how halogens are distributed between minerals in oceanic rocks that dove back into the deep Earth. We showed that while chlorine gets expelled from the plate once it starts diving back into the deep Earth, other halogen elements like fluorine may hold still. Therefore, fractionations between different halogen elements can be used to decipher the source of volcanic rocks. By analyzing hydrogen in other oceanic rocks, we showed that minerals in oceanic plates contain much more hydrogen than previously thought. Using other deep recycled rocks, we showed that certain elemental ratios help decipher the composition of fluids that are expelled deep into the Earth in subduction zones.

Beyond science and technology, this project contributed to the training of PhD students who have acquired a rigorous scientific approach applicable to all domains of society. Results from this project contribute to a better understanding of the subduction process, on which future studies can build to further advance our knowledge of geological hazards in the US and worldwide.
